comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: This train? may be in the Repair shop but I doubt it is in for repair! rather it looks like it is scrapped or being cannibalised for other uses. See www.leitrimguardian.ie/2003/Cavan%20Leitrim%20Railway.pdf " In 1925 all the railways in the Free State, including the Cavan & Leitrim were merged as the Great Southern Railway Co. The amalgamation, as it was called, marked the start of the decline of the narrow gauge. Its workshops were stripped of much of their machinery, and many of the tradesmen were transferred or became redundant. All major engine repairs were sent to Inchicore." Is (was) it a Narrow Guage Engine?

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: I might say that it's probably a standard gauge loco, judging from the length, and the size of the pistons. I'd agree with Danny it doesn't look too good, probably been cannibalised for other uses. The C&L had much smaller engines, so I might assume this photo is probably taken elsewhere on the county, maybe in Inchicore, but where would involve a bit of detective work!

comment.author: 61286047@N00
comment._content: I'm afraid the ODEA link doesn't work. Should be catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000304159

comment.author: 61286047@N00
comment._content: It may have been abandoned may years before the photo was made.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: How about Cavan & Leitrim Railway 4-4-0T narrow-gauge tank engine? These had outside cylinders, a round-topped firebox, and solid wheels on the leading bogie. "Nos.5 and 6 were scrapped in 1925 and 1927. The others gradually lost their names except No.3 Isabel, which retained hers until withdrawal in 1949. No.7 had been cut up in 1945, but the remaining four lasted until the closure of the line in April 1959. No.3 has gone to the USA for preservation in working order near New York." Here is a route map, the western terminus being the coal mines at Arigna. Here is Arigna Station on OSI historic map There is a railway water tank by the roadside at Drumshanbo on Google Street View. Don't run into this in the dark.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/flyingsnail] I'll have to leave engine, gauge, etc. to you experts, but this shot was taken at Arigna. It's one of a series taken by Mr O'Dea on Tuesday, 28 April 1959. Sorry that digitised images are not attached to the catalogue records for ye to have a look at...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/rienkmebius] Apologies about the glitchy link. Fixed now, thanks for the heads up.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Thanks for the OSI accuracy. I was a bit off (shocker!). And the OSI Historic Map definitely says C & L R (Cavan & Leitrim Railway) for the Ballinamore and Arigna Branch.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Would imagine this is another example of Mr O'Dea capturing the last gasp of a railway station/line, as this line closed March/April 1959, and he took this photo on 28th April?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: I don't think there was a loco repair shop at Arigna. The only workshops on the C&L were at Ballinamore, which was frequented heavily by photographers like O'Dea. This is where I suspect the photos is taken if it is a C&L machine we are looking at. The workshop buildings are now incorporated into a school, which the old station at Ballinamore was converted to after closure.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: I have just followed the railway route on OSI aerial view to the disused Arigna Iron Works. This line must have been built after the historic map. Maybe the loco was cut up at the Iron Works and went straight into the furnace.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] It would have been post-closure on the C&L, with the last train running on 31st March 1959. The reference to demolition train in the other photos captured that day, usually refers to the train which was engaged in the dismantling of the track and infrastructure on the line. I've just looked at some of the C&L locos and the photos appears to match them, just that the engine has been dismantled beyond recognition to determine which one(!), probably withdrawn in the mid 1940s and early 1950s. The line to Arigna coal mines was opened in 1920, which explains its absence on the OS.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: This gets more interesting. Here is a photo of the aerial ropeway at Arigna, with narrow-gauge railway tracks. There is only one of these aerial ropeways remaining in the UK, at a brickworks in Claughton. Remember the closing scenes of "Get Carter" with Michael Caine?

comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content: One of the C&L engines survives at Cultra (Ulster Folk & Transport Museum), saw it today in fact during a visit there!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/flyingsnail] Will I have a look at the Ballinamore Wagon Shop photos we have as a check?

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: yes, it's probably being cut up for scrap. Seems a bit too "cut back" for simple maintenance. Those GM locos we saw a while ago largely replaced the steamies by the 1960's, see www.irrs.ie/Journal%20175/175%20B121.htm, so this would be the final resting place for the steam loco I believe...

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content: Another EBAY "as is".

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: Definitely being broken up. section of the flange on cylinder to take cylinder head has been smashed. evidence of gas cutting on plates between cylinders.

comment._content: Its either 4L(Violet)  or 8L (Queen Victoria) being cut possibly in Ballinamore Works one month after the line closed, her two sisters survive to this day No2 Kathleen at the Ulster Folk and Transport Museum in Cultra
